results.title: Harley-Davidson sinks as expectations reversed
results.content:
A case of mis-managing expectations by Harley-Davidson?

Shares in the motorbike maker jumped 6 per cent on April 22 after the release of better than expected first-quarter results and a bright outlook for the year.

Fast forward three months and Harley'-Davidson's shares are the biggest decliners on the S&P 500 on Tuesday after the company cut its outlook for full-year shipments.

Harley-Davidson is forecasting a 3.5 per cent to 5.5 per cent rise in shipments this year from 2013. In April, it had predicted growth of between 7 per cent and 9 per cent.

The company pinned the blame on poor weather and a lull in sales of the Sportster models before the release of new models later this year.

Harley Davidson shares were down 6 per cent at $62.96 in late morning trading in New York.

results.title: EU ministers fail to agree new Russia sanctions
results.content:
EU foreign ministers failed to agree new sanctions against Russia at a Brussels meeting on Tuesday and instead tasked their diplomats to explore possible wider-ranging measures this week.

Although such measures could include cutting off access to Europe's capital markets and an arms embargo, they would be contingent on whether Russia fails to cooperate in the future, not on past behaviour - like ties to the downing of MH17, reports the FT's Peter Spiegel in Brussels.
results.abstract: EU foreign ministers failed to agree new sanctions against Russia at a Brussels meeting on Tuesday and instead tasked their diplomats to explore possible wider-ranging measures this week.

results.title: US court deals a blow to Obamacare
results.content:
A US appeals court has delivered a potentially significant blow to President Barack Obama's signature healthcare law, ruling that tax subsidies provided under the legislation may be unlawful in more than half of the country.

The DC court agreed with plaintiffs who argued the Affordable Care Act only granted the government the ability to offer subsidies in states that set up their own insurance marketplaces.

The decision could hit the law, as just 14 states have created their own health insurance marketplaces. The three-judge panel found the law "does not authorize the Internal Revenue Service to provide tax credits for insurance purchased on federal exchanges".

Most states, particularly those with Republican leadership, have opposed the law and forced consumers to buy insurance through the federal government.

The subsidies greatly reduce the cost of health insurance for middle- and low-income Americans.

According to figures from the Kaiser Foundation, a family of four with a household income of $60,000 could receive more than $4,000 a year in subsidies.

The White House can the appeal ruling.
results.abstract: A US appeals court has delivered a potentially significant blow to President Barack Obama's signature healthcare law, ruling that tax subsidies provided under the legislation may be unlawful in more than half of the country.

results.title: US housing sales stir from slumber
results.content:
Good news for America's estate agents.

The sale of previously owned homes rebounded more than expected last month, according to figures from the National Association of Realtors.

The volume of sales climbed 2.6 per cent to annualised rate of 5.04m - the first time the 5m mark has been breached since October.

Economists had predicted the rate would rise 1.9 per cent to an annualised rate of 4.99m.

Although the pace of activity in the housing market has picked up over the last couple of months, it remains well shy of the rates reached last year,

It touched a recent peak of 5.38m in July last year. A couple of years of double-digit house prices rise and higher mortgage rates (at least from a year ago) have tempered the pace of housing sales.

results.title: Inflation figures have a sting for US bulls
results.content:
The initial reaction suggests bond and stock investors enjoyed the latest snapshot of US inflation. And why not?

Figures from the Labor Department show the core rate, a measure of prices that excludes energy and food, didn't rise as much in June as forecast.

That, on balance, will ease any anxiety that building inflation pressures could force Janet Yellen and her colleagues at the Federal Reserve to pull the trigger on an interest rate increase quicker than they would otherwise want.

Michelle Girard, an economist at Royal Bank of Scotland, said of the figures that a:

Relatively tame reading this summer should alleviate concerns that inflation is beginning to break to the upside.

Futures on the S&P 500, whose rally since 2009 has been helped by the Fed's stimulus programme, climbed in pre-market trading.

Treasuries, which have been at the heart of the central bank's stimulus plan, erased their losses as yields moved lower.

However, there's a sting or two in the figures.

Yes, prices for certain categories fell. Car and truck prices fell 0.4 per cent; a measure of rates for hotels dropped 1.9 per cent and airline fares, after surging 5.8 per cent in May, had a much smaller decline last month.

But headline inflation - the rate that matters to consumers - rose as economists had predicted. The 0.3 per cent increase from May kept the annual rate at 2.1 per cent.

A 3.3 per cent surge in gasoline prices accounted for some of the jump, and left the energy index up 3.2 per cent in the last 12 months.

Although food prices had a smaller rise (0.1 per cent in June vs 0.5 per cent in May), the index for the cost of food consumed at home is up 2.4 per cent over the last 12 months.

While taking some pressure off the Fed, the inflation figures also underline the headwinds facing the consumers who are central to prospects of the US economy picking up pace in the second half of the year.

Little wonder bond investors are becalmed.
results.abstract: The initial reaction suggests bond and stock investors enjoyed the latest snapshot of US inflation. And why not?

results.title: Tyrie v RBS: profit centre or "profit centre"?
results.content:
Royal Bank of Scotland once again on the naughty step this morning.

Another political mini-barmy has broken out between Andrew Tyrie, chairman of the UK's powerful Treasury Select Committee, and RBS over whether a controversial unit at the state-owned bank that dealt with distressed loans to small businesses was or was not a "profit centre."

RBS executives clashed with MPs last month in over whether the business, known as "GRG," was improperly incentivised to maximise its returns, at the expense of the struggling businesses it was tasked with dealing with.

On Tuesday, Mr Tyrie crowed that RBS had now apparently conceded that GRG was in fact a "profit centre" - the conclusion reached by Sir Andrew Large, a former banker who was asked by RBS to investigate its treatment of small businesses:

In a hearing with the Treasury Committee in June, RBS flatly contradicted Sir Andrew Large's description of GRG as a profit centre. A month later, RBS now accepts that GRG was a profit centre after all.

RBS had not objected to the term 'profit centre' when given extensive opportunity to comment on drafts of Sir Andrew's report last year.

Yet it decided to contest the term in evidence to the Committee, not only in a written statement in February, but also repeatedly in its public hearing in June.

Following the Committee's decision to write to Sir Andrew Large for clarification, RBS has now offered the Committee what it euphemistically describes as 'additional comments'. In fact, they have done a belated U-turn. It's not as if the facts have changed. So it now appears that RBS has been wilfully obtuse with the Committee.

If this is how RBS deals with a parliamentary Committee, how much can customers and regulators rely on it to be straightforward with them?

So far, so political point scoring.

But is that what RBS actually said?

We'll let readers judge for themselves. Here's the full excerpt from RBS's explanatory letter to the committee - emphais ours:

Firstly, with regard to the term of 'profit centre' we wish to make clear we do not disagree with the way that that accounting term was used by Sir Andrew Large in his report.

Sir Andrew clearly set out his definition for that accounting term in his glossary and it is indeed the case that the financial performance of GRG was monitored to enable us to understand GRG'S financial performance.

This is a standard accounting practice across all sectors of our business (for example our Property Service division, which exists to support amongst other things our branch network, can also be classified as a profit centre by virtue of its recordings of assets, as well as costs and income).

However, what Mr Sach and I were taking issue with is the way others have used Sir Andrew's report to suggest that GRG had a profit motive with a prejudice against our customers, rather than a turnaround motive. Indeed as Mr Sach pointed out in his evidence, far from making any profit for the bank, GRG has recorded a substantial loss over recent years.

Put simply, GRG deals with many customers who cannot service their debts, leading to losses for the bank.
results.abstract: Royal Bank of Scotland once again on the naughty step this morning.

results.title: Saudi bourse rises to 6-year high on reform talk
results.content:
Saudi Arabia's market has climbed to a six-year high on the authorities' plans to open up the bourse to direct foreign investment for the first time, a move that would likely entice a slew of money managers keen to tap into the oil-rich economy.

The Tadawul All-Shares index has gained 2.9 per cent today – the biggest advance in over three years and the best performance of any market in the world today.

The move has been long-rumoured, but has been slowed down for years by Saudi Arabia's conservatism and entrenched inertia (a mortgage law has been in limbo for almost a decade).

The government said late on Monday that it has allowed the Capital Markets Authority to grant foreigners the right to buy and sell shares "at a time it sees as appropriate". No timetable has been given, but reports speculate that it could happen early next year.

This is a big deal for international investors, as this earlier fastFT story says.
results.abstract: Saudi Arabia's market has climbed to a six-year high on the authorities' plans to open up the bourse to direct foreign investment for the first time, a move that would likely entice a slew of money managers keen to tap into the oil-rich economy.

results.title: Italian parliament lifts immunity for Forza Italia MP
results.content:
Italy's lower chamber has voted in favour of lifting parliamentary immunity for Giancarlo Galan, member of parliament for Silvio Berlusconi's Forza Italia party and a former minister, thus paving the way for his arrest.

In the secret vote on Tuesday, 395 members of parliament voted in favour and 138 against, reports Giulia Segreti in Rome.

Mr Galan is under investigation for alleged corruption in a bribery scandal relating to the Mose flood barrier project in Venice. In June, prosecutors issued a warrant for Mr Galan, who could not be arrested because of his parliamentary status.

He is currently hospitalised in the city of Este, close to Padua, where he lives.

Antonio Franchini, a lawyer for Mr Galan, said he would file a request for a home arrest.

More soon on ft.com

results.title: Lonmin: new chairman, same intractable problems
results.content:
At least change at the top of Lonmin solves one problem at the South African platinum miner as it dusts itself down after a bruising five-month mineworkers' strike.

The confirmation of Brian Beamish as chairman of the London-listed company will ensure that it is run by someone with operational experience of the complexities of South African mining - including platinum mining - from almost two-score years in the Anglo American stable.

Not that Anglo American's platinum subsidiary, best known as Amplats, has been the model of efficiency it could have been. It left serious cost-cutting far too late to get ahead of the falling cycle, and its hands are in any case tied by a government intent on avoiding the job losses the industry has long required amid so much surplus capacity.

The trouble for Lonmin, as a smaller contender in the market that Amplats dominates, is that it has even less financial wiggle room than Anglo. In recent memory, it has lumbered from crisis to crisis, its progress punctuated by rights issues to puncture debt boils, and it ultimately relies for its long-run survival on Amplats shedding capacity.

That seems ever more unlikely to happen given that Amplats is merely trying to exit unprofitable deep-level mines the better to concentrate on its mechanised Mogalakwena mine and other more promising assets. Low-margin capacity will be replaced by higher-margin stuff. Amplats even plans to exit its ominously-named Pandora joint venture with Lonmin.

A further factor weighing on Lonmin is the as yet unknown intention of Glencore with regard to its 24.5 per cent stake. It is hard to imagine that it is a keeper in the long run.

And, its beyond operational challenges, that is another uncertainty for Lonmin in an industry that is crying out for proper consolidation. As we said yesterday, the Amplats platinum assets are not the only ones on the market.

While Mr Beamish gets a grip on these issues, investors are left to look for signs that CEO Ben Magara is indeed on his way to building a "robust and sustainable Lonmin", with a first glimpse of that when the miner releases its third quarter production report and interim management statement on Friday. Thereafter, keep a close eye on costs in subsequent reporting periods - and marvel at the magnitude of the task facing the dependable Mr Magara.
results.abstract: At least change at the top of Lonmin solves one problem at the South African platinum miner as it dusts itself down after a bruising five-month mineworkers' strike.

results.title: US core inflation rate eased in June
results.content:
And relax. The big US economic data release of the week has come in almost exactly as was expected.

Consumer prices climbed 0.3 per cent in June, with a sharp rise in gas prices pushing the annual rate of inflation to 2.1 per cent, the Labor Department said in a report on Tuesday.

The core rate, which is of more significance to policymakers at the Federal Reserve, if not American consumers having to pay higher gas prices, fell shy of the 0.2 per cent increase forecast.

It rose 0.1 per cent from May, leaving the annual rate at 1.9 per cent.

With hopes that US growth will pick up in the second half of the year, the possibility of that fanning inflation is edging onto investors' radars.

Janet Yellen, the Fed chairwoman, has so far played down the threat of rising prices given the lack of wage growth in the economy.

Treasuries were little changed in the wake of the figures, with the yield on the ten-year note up 1 basis point at 2.48 per cent. S&P 500 futures edged higher.
results.abstract: And relax. The big US economic data release of the week has come in almost exactly as was expected.
